subject: Re: I can't assign ah/awe/ox, and the helpful chart made it worse.  Help?
msgSnippet: ... I was born in North Carolina, but spent some seriously formative years near Washington DC and then Winchester, VA, which is appalachian territory.  But my
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:

> They are all the same for some people, basically in the western U.S.
> If you tell us where you live (or grew up), we may be able to help further.

I was born in North Carolina, but spent some seriously formative years near Washington DC and then Winchester, VA, which is appalachian territory. But my sister did all of the same things and she confided in me once that her friends occasionally ask her where I'm from because we don't sound the same.

> The word's not ideal, because some people pronounce the "l" though most
> do not. But this whole group is miscellaneous: some words that kept their
> sounds through the Great Vowel Shift, like "father"; the "alm" words;
> and various foreign words like "salaam", "Brahms", "sonata", "iguana".

I don't pronounce the l in palm, but the a is very very different from father. Like I said, it's a lot closer to awe than ah. It's definitely a monophthong, it hold its position from start to finish. I can't get a better grip on it, my opinion keeps changing, it's hard to hear sometimes.

> This sounds like you are from the eastern U.S., where "lot" and "father" have
> the same vowel quality (the vowel in "lot" is automatically shorter
> than in "father" because the syllable is closed by the final "t"),
> and so do "cloth" and "thaw".
>
> If that's true, you really do have only two vowels for the three Read
> letters, which means you simply have to learn when to use Ox and when to
> use Ah. Basically, it depends on whether the written word in ordinary
> spelling has "o" or "a".

Thank you.

> Are you sure? "Thought" is *written* with two letters, and it is
> subject to automatic shortening for the same reason as "lot", but the
> vowel quality of "thought" and "thaw" is usually the same.

Well, I kept doing research, and I think *someone* knows what I'm talking about. Found this: http://www.ic.arizona.edu/~anth383/lexicalsets.html and their list for thought is taught, naughty, ought, taut, applaud, autumn, hawk, jaw, chalk, all, bald, halt, alter, fault. The thing that gives me hope about this list is it's perfectly even. From taught to autumn they all have the taught vowel, from hawk to fault they all have the thaw vowel. (Hey! Another minimal pair: fought/fault. That one is very distinct, more than pause/paws.) Broad is another notable thought vowel because of its different spelling from the others. I think I need to buy that book.

Honestly my search now is just for the IPA for thought. It starts out with the lips more rounded than thaw, but not so round as it is for boo, then the lips relax by the end of it. The jaw lowers through the vowel, and finally, I *think* the tongue is moving back. Except for the lips, it begins very much like awe. I have no idea where it ends, saying it too much has ruined my ear, same as what happened to palm.
